thread.title: Giant 600 tonne arches of the Ordsall Chord lifted into place - latest pictures and updates
thread.title_full: Giant 600 tonne arches of the Ordsall Chord lifted into place - latest pictures and updates

author: Charlotte Cox
title: Giant 600 tonne arches of the Ordsall Chord lifted into place - latest pictures and updates
text:
Share this video Watch Next 
Today the giant 600 tonne arches of the Ordsall Chord will be painstakingly lowered into place - and the M.E.N will cover this historic moment live from the site near Irwell Street in Salford. 
Forming a major part of the railway link between Piccadilly and Victoria stations, the arches will be slowly suspended then inched into place by two giant cranes - one the biggest in Europe, the other the largest in the UK. 
The momentous feat of engineering has already begun this morning and will take more than four hours in total. 
The £85m Ordsall Chord - 300m of new track - aims at allowing more trains to cross the north and boost passenger capacity. Read More Major section of £85m Ordsall Chord completed over festive break 
And the project, created by architect Peter Jenkins, BDP transport architect director, is more than just a bridge. 
There will also be a footbridge from which there will be a view of the historic Stephenson’s Bridge, built in 1830 by George Stephenson, the ‘father of railways’. 
Surrounded by piazzas and walkways, the Trinity Way project will also create a public space, with shops and wine bars planned for beneath the old arches to be preserved on site. 
In all, there will be 7,000 sqm of public spaces and 2,000 sqm of Yorkstone-paved pedestrian routes. 
The arches were manufactured by Severfield near Bolton. 10:04 
Another timelapse shows the arches being moved closer and closer into place. 10:01 Bridge will link Piccadilly and Victoria 
The completed bridge and Ordsall Chord will link Victoria and Piccadilly railway stations. 09:57 09:54 Video shows giant cranes lifting arches 
Photographer Vincent Cole is at the site near Irwell Street in Salford where the work is taking place today. 09:50 Slow process 
It is a slow process and it is expected to take several hours for the arches to be lifted into place. 
This timelapse footage shows the arches being moved slowly earlier this morning. 09:47 Giant arches being lifted into place 
Today the giant 600 tonne arches of the Ordsall Chord will be painstakingly lowered into place - and the M.E.N will cover this historic moment live from the site near Irwell Street in Salford. 
Forming a major part of the railway link between Piccadilly and Victoria stations, the arches will be slowly suspended then inched into place by two giant cranes - one the biggest in Europe, the other the largest in the UK. 
The momentous feat of engineering has already begun this morning and will take more than four hours in total. One of the arches are lifted into place Share
